content.text: Use the ruler in Fig. 1.1 to determine the length of the piece of wire
length of wire =   .........  \(cm\)
State the name of an instrument the student can use to measure mass
The student determines the volume of the wire
He uses a measuring cylinder part-filled with water and places the wire in it, as shown in Fig. 1.2
Determine the volume of the wire by using information in Fig. 1.2
volume of wire =   .........  \(cm^3\)
The student folds the piece of wire and measures its mass
The student measures the mass and the volume of a piece of metal
The mass of the piece of metal is \(93.6 \text{g}\) and its volume is \(12 \text{cm}^3\)
Calculate the density of the metal
density of metal =   .........  \(g / cm^3\)
A student uses a ruler to measure the length of a piece of wire, as shown in Fig. 1.1
On the line next to each stop-watch, write the time it shows
Calculate the average time for the trolley to roll down the slope
average time =   .........  \(s\)
The students want the same trolley to take more time to roll down the plank
Suggest how the students alter the arrangement in Fig. 2.1
A different trolley travels \(1.2 \text{m}\) down the slope in a time of \(7.8 \text{s}\)
Calculate the average speed of the trolley
average speed =   .........  m/s
The trolley travels down a different slope. Fig. 2.3 shows the speed–time graph
Calculate the distance travelled by the trolley between time \(= 0\) and time \(= 4.0 \text{s}\)
distance travelled =   .........  m
A slope is made by resting one end of a plank of wood on a block, as shown in Fig. 2.1
Two students each use a digital stop-watch to measure the time for a small trolley to roll down the full length of the slope
Fig. 2.2 shows the times on the stop-watches
A student determines the centre of mass of a piece of card. Fig. 3.1 shows the equipment the student uses
Describe how the student determines the centre of mass of the card using the equipment in Fig. 3.1
Another card is pivoted at point P. The weight of the card is \(1.4 \text{N}\) and acts through a point \(20 \text{cm}\) from P
Fig. 3.2 shows the arrangement
Calculate the moment of the weight of the card about point P
moment of weight =   .........  N cm

A substance cools from \(50^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(5.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). Its melting point is \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The substance takes 30 minutes to cool from \(50^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to its melting point
The substance takes a total time of 80 minutes to cool from \(50^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(5.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
On Fig. 4.1, sketch a graph that shows how the temperature of the substance varies with time as it cools from \(50^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(5.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Describe the arrangement and motion of the molecules in the substance when they are in the solid state
The weight of the bottle and liquid is \(12 \text{N}\). The area of the bottle in contact with the bench is \(25 \text{cm}^2\)
Calculate the pressure of the bottle on the bench
pressure on bench =   .........  N/cm²

A student pours out all the liquid from the bottle. She then connects the bottle to a vacuum pump which removes most of the air from the bottle. Fig. 5.2 shows the bottle after most of the air is removed
Explain why the bottle is crushed. Use your ideas about molecules
Fig. 5.1 shows a plastic bottle on a bench. The plastic bottle contains a liquid
State the letter P, Q, R, S or T on Fig. 6.1 that represents the wavelength of the water wave
State the letter P, Q, R, S or T on Fig. 6.1 that represents the amplitude of the water wave
State what is meant by the term frequency of a wave
Fig. 6.1 shows part of a water wave
Two students, A and B, use echoes to measure the speed of sound
Student A has two blocks of wood that make a loud sound when banged together. Student B has a stop-watch. They stand \(120 \text{m}\) from a school wall as shown in Fig. 6.2
Describe how the students use the arrangement in Fig. 6.2 to determine the speed of sound in air
draw the path of the refracted ray in the air
mark, and label with the letter \(i\), the angle of incidence
mark, and label with the letter \(r\), the angle of refraction
On Fig. 7.1:
When the angle of incidence at X is \(70^{\circ}\), the ray does **not** emerge from the glass into the air
State what happens to the ray at X and explain why this happens
Visible light and X-rays are travelling through a vacuum
Compare their speed and frequency by completing the sentences
The speed of visible light is ............................................ the speed of X-rays
The frequency of visible light is ............................................ the frequency of X-rays
Describe **one** use of X-rays
Visible light is one part of the electromagnetic spectrum. X-rays are also part of the electromagnetic spectrum

Fig. 7.1 shows a ray of red light entering a semicircular glass block. The ray strikes the flat surface of the block at X and emerges into the air. Fig. 7.1 does not show the path of the refracted ray in the air
On Fig. 8.1, label the north and south poles of the magnet, using the letters N and S.
A soft-iron bar is positioned as shown in Fig. 8.2
State and explain what happens to the soft-iron bar
Fig. 8.1 shows the magnetic field pattern around a bar magnet
A plastic rod is rubbed with a cloth. The plastic rod becomes positively charged
Explain how the friction between the cloth and the rod causes the rod to become positively charged
Use your ideas about the movement of charge
Plastic is an electrical insulator. Iron is an electrical conductor
State two other materials that are electrical conductors
State the name of the instrument used to measure potential difference (p.d.) in an electric circuit
State the unit for the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of a battery
A student connects a circuit to determine the resistance of a wire. The current in the wire is 0.20A when the potential difference across the wire is 6.4V
Calculate the resistance of the wire
resistance =   .........  \(\Omega\)
The student has some wires of the same material as those in **(b)**(i) but of various lengths and thicknesses. He wants a wire with higher resistance than the wire in **(b)**(i)
State **two** ways of identifying a wire with a higher resistance by comparing its length and thickness with the wire in **(b)**(i)
This question is about electric circuits
Describe how the student uses the equipment
State two ways in which the student can increase the size of the induced e.m.f
A student plans to demonstrate the induction of an electromotive force (e.m.f.) in a wire
He has a length of wire, a sensitive centre-reading galvanometer and a permanent magnet
On Fig. 10.1, draw an arrow between the poles of the magnet to show the direction of the magnetic field
State two ways of making the coil spin faster
State one way of making the coil spin in the opposite direction
Fig. 10.1 shows a d.c. motor
\(\alpha\) (alpha)-particles, \(\beta\) (beta)-particles and \(\gamma\) (gamma)-rays have different characteristics
Complete Table 11.1 by indicating the correct type of radiation for each characteristic. The first one is done for you
A sample of radioactive material contains \(80 \text{mg}\) of sodium-24
The half-life of sodium-24 is 15 hours
Calculate the mass of sodium-24 remaining in the sample after 45 hours
mass remaining =   .........  \(mg\)
